utterances: Bledsoe's concerns have played out in Texas, which has tried implementing an even larger effort to privatize social services.
But Texas's contract with Accenture hasn't been fully implemented because of what are termed transitional problems that created a backlog of 7,000 food stamp applications.
Celia Hagert, a senior policy analyst with the Center for Public Policy Priorities in Austin, says while the Indiana contract doesn't privatize as many services, there are striking similarities.
It's a little bit uncanny, a little bit creepy to read the reports of what's being decided in Indiana, because you just replace the word Indiana with Texas and it's the same story.
And I really think that it's important for Indiana to learn from, you know, Texas' mistakes and move more slowly.
Hagert says that in Texas, pink slips went to nearly 2,000 state workers when Accenture took over.
Indiana's governor says no jobs will be lost at the onset of the IBM contract.
But still, many state workers like Elizabeth Walker are wary.
She says state governments should not be contracting out large parts of social services.
To take that part of government that deals with the most vulnerable of our community and give it to a private contractor for profit, to me, is just not right.
But Governor Daniels says a strong private sector benefits everyone.
People are defending an indefensibly terrible system.
And their only reason is some vague notion that there's something wrong with making a profit.
Federal approval for Daniel's plan could come as early as next week.
States across the country will watch Indiana's results closely to see if they hold promise for their own problems delivering social services.
For NPR News, I'm Marianne Holland in Indianapolis.
It's been a week for the political history books in this country.
Barack Obama's nomination for president inspired figures all along the political spectrum.
Here are just a few voices:
I never thought I would live to see it but now it can happen.
I think and believe that this nomination, I hope the election, of Barack Obama will bring an end to that heritage of racism that existed ever since our nation was founded.
Just seeing him on stage, I cried my eyelashes off.

I woke up this morning and I went to Google and I looked at the Martin Luther King full speech from 45 years ago where he talked about the promise of democracy and tonight I feel that that promise was fulfilled.
This is a wonderful occasion because I think it is, as the March on Washington was, a marvelous symbol of this country's continuing struggle to be who it wants to says to be.
I think it would make Dr. King very, very happy and that the country, I think, has hope again.
I think all over America and many parts of the world, the hopes, the longings, the aspiration and the dreams will be hanging on every word that he's saying.
It's going to be incredible.
That was Congressman and long-time civil rights leader John Lewis, and before that Maya Angelou, former President Jimmy Carter, Oprah Winfrey, and children's rights activist Marian Wright Edelman.
Tanks and missiles rolled across Moscow's Red Square today.
It was the first time since the end of communism that such military hardware played a role in the annual Victory in Europe Parade.
Russia is borrowing a page from the Soviet Union to show that it is back on the world stage, even though experts say the country's military is in a shambles.
NPR's Moscow correspondent Gregory Feifer was at Red Square today.
Tank trends clutter over the cobblestones of Red Square.
Hearing them today, you'd be forgiven for believing you'd gone back in time 17 years.
That's when Russians last saw heavy military equipment ramble through central Moscow.
My name is Caroline Funkhauser.
I'm 16 years old.
I've never been a Girl Scout, never had much interest in it.
I always thought it was a girly thing, and I'm not much of a girly girl.

The Girl Scouts know they face more competition than ever for young girls' attention, but they say today's Scouts do a lot more than past generations, things like white water rafting, running web sites and survival camping.
For example, this February I slept out in 13-degree weather, and I think that's really cool.
There's nothing girly about that.
Seventeen-year-old Kaela Gisherman was among 60 middle and high school-aged girls at a recent Girl Scout workshop near Boston, where they used pretend budgets to practice money management.
(Soundbite of Girl Scout workshop)
Unidentified Woman #1: On day one we have to add the 30 dollars.
Unidentified Woman #2: This is lifelike basically, absolutely.
Welcome to the real world, girls!
The girls also learn how to cook on a hotplate, change a fuse, and unclog a toilet.
Some of the skills that program director Wendy Garf-Lipp says they'll need when they leave home for college.
We try and present a variety of different programs that will give the girls the strength of character to move on when they leave Girl Scouts and live independently.
I don't think we've done the best job possible in getting the word out there what Girl Scouts really is.
Only about 10 percent of American girls are involved with Girl Scouts, a number that has held steady for decades.
But the Scouts plan to start targeting the other 90 percent with their most aggressive PR strategy to date.
CEO Kathy Cloninger just hired the organization's first ever marketing director to revitalize their brand.

We are looking for partnerships where we put Girl Scouting into the middle of girl culture and we use spokespeople and marketing campaigns, the Internet, and Facebook, and however, you know, wherever girls hang out.
That's where we are trying to get them with new messages about what Girl Scouting really is.
The Girl Scouts also charge their in-house research institute to study how girls feel about the organization's core mission to train future women leaders.
Research director Judy Schoenberg.
What we heard from thousands of girls is that they are really turned off by the commanding control, top down type of leadership that they see so much around them.
They really aspire to a type of leadership that is about making a difference in the world and social change.
The Scouts want to give girls more say in how they learn to be leaders.

So, this spring, in addition to the traditional programs led by troop leaders, CEO Kathy Cloninger says they'll be new programs called leadership journeys that will be planned and directed by the Girl Scouts themselves.
So, they are following their own girl interests, so we're working to help adults step back a bit, and to encourage girls to step up.
The Girl Scouts plan to roll out new TV, magazine, and web content this fall, and they're focusing on attracting more black, Hispanic and Asian girls.
The Scouts say they'll be watching closely to see who takes notice.
For NPR News, I'm Shannon Mullin.
From NPR News, this is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Farai Chideya.
Later today, President Bush is expected to rule out a plan to increase troops in Iraq by 20,000 to a total of just under a 160,000.
This is despite the fact that Americans continue to sour on the war and many military and political officials call for withdrawal.
Even U.S.
troops are split over how to deal with the violence in Iraq.
Some have launched campaigns to get their colleagues to speak out against the war.
We'll talk to one of them in a moment, Jonathan Hutto, creator of the Appeal for Redress.
Others like former Army Sergeant Neal Saunders say the U.S.
must stay and fight.
Saunders went to Iraq in March of 2004.
He fought for a year with Task Force 112 of the 1st Cavalry Division.
He lives in Texas now and says troops in Iraq must be allowed to finish the war.
If you're sending soldiers anywhere, it's a soldier's job to fight.
And my support of, you know, what's going on over there now is the fact that we have soldiers there that have trained to fight and that's what they need to be doing.
Some people say at this point in time, you know what, we went there without having all the intelligence information that we needed to have.
We shouldn't have ever gone.
Does that at all affect how you view the need to continue fighting?
My opinion in that matter, when there's people that have trained to do a certain job on the ground, they need to do that job.

And if I'm not willing to, you know, bear that responsibility of fighting a war on my own shoulders, then I shouldn't be so judgmental of those that are and I won't try to do their job for them from the comfort of my own couch.
Do you ever talk about issues with the people that you served with or even with other veterans?
And how do people break out along the lines of stay the course versus we need a change?
It all depends on the mentality of the person that you're talking to.
I talked to, you know, several guys who's been sent out, and they'll tell you the exact same thing that I say all the time.
They'd say, look, we've trained to fight and blow things up, and that's not what's happening.
Therefore, I'm here working outside of my capacity as a professional.
A lot of guys feel as though their hands are tied and they can't do the job that they have been trained to perform.
Then I'll talk to some of the guys that, when we are on our tour, were maybe not as aggressive and maybe, you know, presented themselves as been more scared than others.
You talk to some of those guys and they'll give you a completely, you know, different perspective on the war and what's going on.
And I think theirs comes from a position of we shouldn't be here, you know, let's just wrap this up.
But that comes from their desire to want nothing more than just to go home and not have to be put in such a position, in such a stressful condition because it is hard.
It was almost a year ago that President Obama signed the economic stimulus plan into law.
The $787 billion American Recovery and Reinvestment Act was supposed to jumpstart the economy through tax cuts and job creation.
Here is the president at the bill signing ceremony last February in Denver.
(Soundbite of applause)
Because of this investment, nearly 400,000 men and women will go to work rebuilding our crumbling roads and bridges, repairing our faulty dams and levees.
But according to an analysis conducted by the Associated Press, those new jobs have not affected local unemployment.
AP reporter Matt Apuzzo conducted the analysis and he joins me here in the studio.
And Matt, your findings show those jobs not as promised.
